objectID: 2023-02-21 - Bob Ross Paintings/2023-02-21 - Bob Ross Paintings.html
href: 2023-02-21 - Bob Ross Paintings/2023-02-21 - Bob Ross Paintings.html
title: Bob Ross Paintings
text:
# devtools::install_github("frankiethull/BobRossColors")
# devtools::install_github("ctesta01/ggtriangles")

library(patchwork)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5

library(colorspace)
library(BobRossColors)
library(ggtriangles)


bob_ross <- read_csv(
  "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jwilber/Bob_Ross_Paintings/master/data/bob_ross_paintings.csv") %>% 
  select(-1) %>% 
  mutate(across(Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson, as.logical))

New names:
Rows: 403 Columns: 29
── Column specification

(6): img_src, painting_title, youtube_src, colors, color_hex, tags dbl (23):
...1, painting_index, season, episode, num_colors, Black_Gesso, Br...

Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
• `` -> `...1`

bob_ross %>% 
  glimpse()

Rows: 403
Columns: 28

$ img_src          <chr> "https://www.twoinchbrush.com/images/painting282.webp…

theme_set(theme_minimal())

theme_update(
  
  plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightblue", color = "lightblue"),
  panel.background = element_rect(fill = "lightyellow", color = "lightyellow"),
  
  panel.grid.major=element_blank(),
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  
  axis.title = element_blank(),
  axis.text = element_blank(),
  
  legend.position = "none"
)


How many paintings per season?
There are 13 paintings per season every season for 31 season

bob_ross %>% 
  group_by(season) %>% 
  summarise(paintings = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(paintings))

# A tibble: 31 × 2
   season paintings
    <dbl>     <int>
 1      1        13
 2      2        13
 3      3        13
 4      4        13
 5      5        13
 6      6        13
 7      7        13
 8      8        13
 9      9        13
10     10        13
# ℹ 21 more rows




How many colors does Bob Ross uses per painting ?

bob_ross %>% 
  summarise(median=median(num_colors))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  median
   <dbl>
1     11

bob_ross %>% 
  count(num_colors, sort=T) %>% 
  summarise(mean = weighted.mean(num_colors, n))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
   mean
  <dbl>
1  10.7

bob_ross %>% 
  count(num_colors, sort=T) %>% 
  arrange(num_colors) %>% 
  add_tally(n, name="total_paintings") %>% 
  mutate(sum_colors = cumsum(n),
         perc = round(sum_colors / total_paintings, 2)) 

# A tibble: 14 × 5
   num_colors     n total_paintings sum_colors  perc
        <dbl> <int>           <int>      <int> <dbl>
 1          1     1             403          1  0   
 2          3     4             403          5  0.01
 3          4     4             403          9  0.02
 4          5     5             403         14  0.03
 5          6    11             403         25  0.06
 6          7    23             403         48  0.12
 7          8    26             403         74  0.18
 8          9    30             403        104  0.26
 9         10    44             403        148  0.37
10         11    75             403        223  0.55
11         12    98             403        321  0.8 
12         13    63             403        384  0.95
13         14    12             403        396  0.98
14         15     7             403        403  1   

bob_ross %>% 
  summarise(interval = list(quantile(num_colors, probs = c(0.05, 0.1, 0.9, 0.95)))) %>%
  unnest_wider(interval)

# A tibble: 1 × 4
   `5%` `10%` `90%` `95%`
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1     6     7    13    13

color_numbers <- bob_ross %>% 
  left_join(bob_ross %>% count(num_colors), by="num_colors")

indian_red <- "#CD5C5C"

color_number_plot <- color_numbers %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=num_colors)) + 
  geom_boxplot(aes(y=120), width=10, outliers=F, staplewidth =0.5, fill=indian_red) + 
  
  geom_bar(stat = "count", fill=indian_red) + 
  
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:15) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 100, 20), expand = c(0, 0.1), limits = c(0,130)) +
  
  labs(title="One Color or Many? How Many Colors Make a Masterpiece", 
       x = "Number of colours used by Bob Ross in his paintings", 
       y ="") +
  
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5, size=24),
    axis.text = element_text(),
    axis.title = element_text(),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_line(),
    plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 10, b = 10, l = 10)
  )

color_number_plot








Bob Ross used on average more than 10 colors in his paintings (mean = 10.7 with a median = 11) and up to 15 colors in 7 of them. In 90% of his paintings, between 6 and 13 colors are used.
Bob Ross used only one color of paint in this painting : “Contemplative Lady” was composed using only Van Dyke Brown which he declined in multiple shades.

bob_ross %>%
  filter(num_colors==1)

# A tibble: 1 × 28
  painting_index img_src    painting_title season episode num_colors youtube_src
           <dbl> <chr>      <chr>           <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl> <chr>      
1             89 https://w… Contemplative…     16       6          1 https://ww…
# ℹ 21 more variables: colors <chr>, color_hex <chr>, tags <chr>,
#   Black_Gesso <lgl>, Bright_Red <lgl>, Burnt_Umber <lgl>,
#   Cadmium_Yellow <lgl>, Dark_Sienna <lgl>, Indian_Red <lgl>,
#   Indian_Yellow <lgl>, Liquid_Black <lgl>, Liquid_Clear <lgl>,
#   Midnight_Black <lgl>, Phthalo_Blue <lgl>, Phthalo_Green <lgl>,
#   Prussian_Blue <lgl>, Sap_Green <lgl>, Titanium_White <lgl>,
#   Van_Dyke_Brown <lgl>, Yellow_Ochre <lgl>, Alizarin_Crimson <lgl>

# Contemplative Lady

show_colors_and_paintings(paintings = c("contemplative_lady"))










What are the most frequent colors used by Bob Ross

most_frequent_used_colours <- bob_ross %>% 
  summarise(across(Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson, sum)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson, names_to = "color", values_to = "count") %>% 
  arrange(desc(count)) %>% 
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(color, count)) %>% 
  mutate(color = str_replace_all(color, "_", "")) %>% 
  left_join(unique_bob_ross_colors)

Joining with `by = join_by(color)`

color_palette <- most_frequent_used_colours$color_hex
names(color_palette) <- most_frequent_used_colours$color
color_palette

  TitaniumWhite AlizarinCrimson    VanDykeBrown   CadmiumYellow     YellowOchre 
      "#FFFFFF"       "#4E1500"       "#221B15"       "#FFEC00"       "#C79B00" 
    PhthaloBlue       BrightRed   MidnightBlack        SapGreen    IndianYellow 
      "#0C0040"       "#DB0000"       "#000000"       "#0A3410"       "#FFB800" 
     DarkSienna    PrussianBlue    PhthaloGreen      BlackGesso      BurntUmber 
      "#5F2E1F"       "#021E44"       "#102E3C"       "#000000"       "#8A3324" 
    LiquidClear     LiquidBlack       IndianRed 
      "#FFFFFF"       "#000000"       "#CD5C5C" 

most_frequent_colors_plot <- most_frequent_used_colours %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=fct_reorder(color, count), y=count, fill=color)) + 
  geom_col() + 
  coord_flip() +
  ylim(0, 403) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0,410), expand = c(0,0)) +
  
  scale_fill_manual(values=color_palette) + 
  labs(title="Bob Ross's Favorite Hues", 
       # subtitle="Starting with Titanium White",
       x = NA, y = NA) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5, size=24),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust=0.5, size=16),

    axis.text = element_text(),
    axis.ticks = element_line(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_line(),
    plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 10, b = 10, l = 10)
  )

Scale for y is already present.
Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.

most_frequent_colors_plot









get_luminance <- function(color) {
  rgb_color <- col2rgb(color) / 255
  0.2126 * rgb_color[1,] + 0.7152 * rgb_color[2,] + 0.0722 * rgb_color[3,]
}

legend_colors <- most_frequent_used_colours %>% 
  mutate(
    label = color %>%
      str_split("(?=[A-Z])") %>% 
      map_chr(~ str_c(.x, collapse = " ")) %>% 
      str_c(color_hex, sep="\n"),
    
    text_color = if_else(get_luminance(color_hex) > 0.5, "black", "white")) 
legend_colors

legend_plot <- legend_colors %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y = fct_reorder(color, count), x=0)) + 
  geom_tile(aes(fill=color)) + 
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) + 
  
  geom_text(aes(label=label, color = text_color)) +
  
  scale_color_identity() +
  scale_fill_manual(values=color_palette) 

legend_plot









facet_title <- str_c("Season ", 1:31)
facet_title[-c(1,6,11,16,21,26,31)] <- ""  # Only write the season title for these seasons
names(facet_title) <- 1:31
facet_title

"Season 31" 

all_seasons_colors <- bob_ross %>% 
  pivot_longer(Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson, names_to = "color") %>% 
  mutate(color = str_replace_all(color, "_", "")) %>% 
  filter(value) %>% 
  left_join(most_frequent_used_colours, by="color")

all_seasons_colors

# A tibble: 4,292 × 14
   painting_index img_src   painting_title season episode num_colors youtube_src
            <dbl> <chr>     <chr>           <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl> <chr>      
 1            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 2            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 3            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 4            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 5            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 6            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 7            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…
 8            282 https://… A Walk in the…      1       1          8 https://ww…

# ℹ 7 more variables: colors <chr>, color_hex.x <chr>, tags <chr>, color <chr>,
#   value <lgl>, count <int>, color_hex.y <chr>

all_seasons_plot <- all_seasons_colors %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=episode, y=fct_reorder(color, count))) + 
  geom_tile(aes(color=color, fill=color), width = 1, height = 1) + 
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  facet_wrap(~season, ncol=5, labeller = labeller(season = facet_title), strip.position = "left") + 
  
  scale_color_manual(values=color_palette) + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=color_palette) + 
  
  theme(
    
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightblue"),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "lightyellow"),
    
    panel.grid.major=element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    
    axis.title = element_blank(),
    axis.text = element_blank())

all_seasons_plot









total_width <- 4500 + 4000
legend_width <- 1000
legend_ratio <- legend_width / total_width
all_ratio <- 1 - legend_ratio


design <- "
  123
  124
  12#
"

bob_ross_colors <- all_seasons_plot + legend_plot + color_number_plot + most_frequent_colors_plot +
  plot_layout(design = design, widths = c(all_ratio, legend_ratio, all_ratio)) + 
  plot_annotation(title = "The Joy of Color: Bob Ross's Happy Little Palette",
                  subtitle = "",
                  caption = "Data source: Jared Wilber's data on Bob Ross Paintings via @frankiethull Bob Ross Colors data package",
                  
                  theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 32, hjust = 0.5)))

bob_ross_colors







ggsave("bob_ross_colors.png", bob_ross_colors, path="Plots", width = total_width, height = 7000, units = "px", bg="white")



Which colors are used together

row_occurance <- bob_ross %>% 
  select(painting_index, Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson) %>%
  pivot_longer(Black_Gesso:Alizarin_Crimson, names_to = "color", values_to = "n")


co_occurence <- row_occurance %>%
  left_join(row_occurance, by = "painting_index") %>%
  mutate(occurence = if_else(n.x & n.y, 1, 0)) %>% 
  group_by(color.x, color.y) %>%
  summarise(Occurance = sum(occurence)) %>%
  spread(key = "color.y", value = "Occurance", fill = 0) %>% 
  rename(Color = "color.x")

Warning in left_join(., row_occurance, by = "painting_index"): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
ℹ Row 1 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
ℹ Row 1 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
ℹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
  "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'color.x'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

co_occurence

#   Indian_Yellow <dbl>, Liquid_Black <dbl>, Liquid_Clear <dbl>,
#   Midnight_Black <dbl>, Phthalo_Blue <dbl>, Phthalo_Green <dbl>,
#   Prussian_Blue <dbl>, Sap_Green <dbl>, Titanium_White <dbl>,

colors_used_together <- co_occurence %>% 
  pivot_longer(Alizarin_Crimson:Yellow_Ochre, names_to = "Pair", values_to = "n") %>% 
  mutate(Color = str_replace_all(Color, "_", ""), Pair = str_replace_all(Pair, "_", ""))

colors_used_together %>% 
  arrange(-n)

# A tibble: 324 × 3
# Groups:   Color [18]
   Color           Pair                n
   <chr>           <chr>           <dbl>
 1 TitaniumWhite   TitaniumWhite     400
 2 AlizarinCrimson AlizarinCrimson   380
 3 AlizarinCrimson TitaniumWhite     378
 4 TitaniumWhite   AlizarinCrimson   378
 5 VanDykeBrown    VanDykeBrown      371
 6 TitaniumWhite   VanDykeBrown      369
 7 VanDykeBrown    TitaniumWhite     369
 8 AlizarinCrimson VanDykeBrown      354
 9 VanDykeBrown    AlizarinCrimson   354
10 CadmiumYellow   CadmiumYellow     346
# ℹ 314 more rows

used_together_plot <- colors_used_together %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=fct_reorder(Color, -n), y=fct_reorder(Pair, n))) +
  geom_point(shape=21, aes(colour=Color, fill=Pair, size=n/400), stroke=1.5) +
  
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +

  scale_fill_manual(values=color_palette) + 
  scale_colour_manual(values=color_palette) + 
  
  theme()

used_together_plot

objectID: 2018-04-03 - US Tuition Costs/2018-04-03 - US Tuition Costs.html
href: 2018-04-03 - US Tuition Costs/2018-04-03 - US Tuition Costs.html
title: 2018-04-03 - US Tuition Costs
text:
library(glue)
library(scales)
library(ggtext)
library(ggdist)
library(readxl)
library(paletteer)
library(patchwork)
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1

✔ purrr     1.0.2

theme_set(theme_minimal())

theme_update(
  
  legend.position = "None"
  
  
  
)

font_family <- "Fira Sans"

palette <- c("#D3F2A3FF", "#97E196FF", "#6CC08BFF", "#4C9B82FF", "#217A79FF", "#105965FF", "#074050FF")


label_dollars <- label_currency(accuracy = 1)


us_avg_tuition <- read_xlsx("us_avg_tuition.xlsx")

us_avg_tuition %>% 
  glimpse()

Columns: 13
$ State     <chr> "Alabama", "Alaska", "Arizona", "Arkansas", "California", "C…

$ `2005-06` <dbl> 5840.550, 4632.623, 5415.516, 6082.379, 5527.881, 5406.967, …
$ `2006-07` <dbl> 5753.496, 4918.501, 5481.419, 6231.977, 5334.826, 5596.348, …
$ `2007-08` <dbl> 6008.169, 5069.822, 5681.638, 6414.900, 5672.472, 6227.002, …
$ `2008-09` <dbl> 6475.092, 5075.482, 6058.464, 6416.503, 5897.888, 6284.137, …
$ `2009-10` <dbl> 7188.954, 5454.607, 7263.204, 6627.092, 7258.771, 6948.473, …
$ `2010-11` <dbl> 8071.134, 5759.153, 8839.605, 6900.912, 8193.739, 7748.201, …
$ `2011-12` <dbl> 8451.902, 5762.421, 9966.716, 7028.991, 9436.426, 8315.632, …
$ `2012-13` <dbl> 9098.069, 6026.143, 10133.503, 7286.580, 9360.574, 8792.856,…
$ `2013-14` <dbl> 9358.929, 6012.445, 10296.200, 7408.495, 9274.193, 9292.954,…
$ `2014-15` <dbl> 9496.084, 6148.808, 10413.844, 7606.410, 9186.824, 9298.599,…
$ `2015-16` <dbl> 9751.101, 6571.340, 10646.278, 7867.297, 9269.844, 9748.188,…



us_avg_tuition_longer <- us_avg_tuition %>% 
  pivot_longer(`2004-05`:`2015-16`, names_to = "Season", values_to = "avg_tuition") 


How did tuition costs increased over time ?

us_avg_tuition %>% 
  mutate(difference = `2015-16` - `2004-05`) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(State, difference))) + 
  geom_col(aes(y = `2015-16`), fill = "red") + 
  geom_col(aes(y = `2004-05`), fill = "orange") + 
  geom_col(aes(y = - difference)) +
  coord_flip()







diff_cutoff <- c(0, 0.23, 0.5, 0.75, 1)
diff_cutoff_names <- c("Decrease", "Slow increase", "Below median increase", "Above median increase", "Fast increase", "More than double increase")

us_avg_tuition %>% 
  mutate(difference = `2015-16` - `2004-05`,
         diff_perc = round(difference / `2004-05`, 2),
         diff_group = cut(
           diff_perc, 
           breaks = c(-Inf, diff_cutoff, Inf), 
           labels = diff_cutoff_names,
           right = FALSE),
         diff_group = factor(diff_group, levels=diff_cutoff_names)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(`2004-05`:`2015-16`, names_to = "Season", values_to = "avg_tuition")  %>% 
  filter(Season %in% c("2004-05", "2015-16")) %>% 
  
  ggplot(aes(x = Season, avg_tuition, group=State)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color=Season)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  facet_wrap(diff_group~., nrow=1)







us_avg_tuition %>% 
  mutate(difference = `2015-16` - `2004-05`) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = `2004-05`, y = `2015-16`)) + 
  geom_segment(aes(x = `2004-05`, y = `2004-05`, xend = `2004-05`, yend = `2015-16`, colour = "segment"), size=1, alpha=0.8) + 
  geom_point(size=4, alpha=0.5) + 
  geom_abline(slope = 1, intercept = 0, size=2) + 
  
  lims(x= c(0 , NA), y = c(0 , NA))

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.








# us_avg_tuition %>% 
#   mutate(difference = `2015-16` - `2004-05`,
#          diff_perc = round(difference / `2004-05`, 2)) %>% 
#   ggplot(aes(group=State)) + 
#     geom_point(aes(x="A", y=0)) + 
#     geom_point(aes(x = "B", y=diff_perc))

median_tuition <- us_avg_tuition_longer %>% 
  group_by(Season) %>% 
  summarize(median = median(avg_tuition)) %>% 
  ungroup() 

median_tuition_2005 <- median_tuition %>% filter(Season == "2004-05") %>% head(1) %>% pull(median)
median_tuition_2015 <- median_tuition %>% filter(Season == "2015-16") %>% head(1) %>% pull(median)

us_avg_tuition %>% 
  pivot_longer(`2004-05`:`2015-16`, names_to = "Season", values_to = "avg_tuition")  %>% 
  
  ggplot(aes(x = avg_tuition, y=Season)) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = median_tuition_2005, col = "grey30", lty = "dashed") +
  annotate("text", y = 0.5, x = median_tuition_2005 + 50, label = "Median tuition in 2004/05", size = 3, hjust = 0) +
  annotate("text", y = 0.5, x = median_tuition_2005 - 50, label = label_dollars(median_tuition_2005), size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  
  
  geom_vline(xintercept = median_tuition_2015, col = "grey30", lty = "dashed") +
  annotate("text", y = 0.5, x = median_tuition_2015 + 50, label = "Median tuition in 2015/16", size = 3, hjust = 0) +
  annotate("text", y = 0.5, x = median_tuition_2015 - 50, label = label_dollars(median_tuition_2015),
           size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  
  stat_halfeye(fill_type = "segments", alpha = 0.3) +
  stat_interval() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point", fun = median) +
  
  scale_y_discrete(expand = expansion(add = c(1, 0))) +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format()) +
  
  scale_color_manual(values = palette)








The “lagging university increased faster to get more concentrated around the mean. A few escaped to reach the top
No increase in 2008 yet the trend is consistent as soon as the following year


Average tuition cost trends over time ?


Did cheaper schools made their price increase faster ?

objectID: 2019-02-26 - French Train Delays/2019-02-26 - French Train Delays.html
href: 2019-02-26 - French Train Delays/2019-02-26 - French Train Delays.html
title: French Train Delays
text:
French Train Delays
https://twitter.com/noccaea/status/1095735292206739456


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



theme_set(theme_minimal())


full_trains <- readr::read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2019/2019-02-26/full_trains.csv")

Rows: 5462 Columns: 27
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (4): service, departure_station, arrival_station, comment_delays_on_arr...
dbl (21): year, month, journey_time_avg, total_num_trips, num_of_canceled_tr...
lgl  (2): comment_cancellations, comment_delays_at_departure

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

small_trains <- readr::read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2019/2019-02-26/small_trains.csv") 

Rows: 32772 Columns: 13
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): service, departure_station, arrival_station, delay_cause
dbl (9): year, month, journey_time_avg, total_num_trips, avg_delay_all_depar...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

international_stations <- c("ZURICH", "LAUSANNE", "GENEVE", "ITALIE", "STUTTGART", "FRANCFORT", "MADRID", "BARCELONA")

is_international <- function(x){x %in% international_stations}

small_trains <- small_trains %>% 
  mutate(service = if_else(is.na(service), 
                           if_else(is_international(departure_station) | is_international(arrival_station), "International", "National"), 
                           service))

small_trains %>% 
  glimpse

Rows: 32,772
Columns: 13
$ year                    <dbl> 2017, 2017, 2017, 2017, 2017, 2017, 2017, 2017…
$ month                   <dbl> 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9, 9…
$ service                 <chr> "National", "National", "National", "National"…
$ departure_station       <chr> "PARIS EST", "REIMS", "PARIS EST", "PARIS LYON…
$ arrival_station         <chr> "METZ", "PARIS EST", "STRASBOURG", "AVIGNON TG…
$ journey_time_avg        <dbl> 85.13378, 47.06452, 116.23494, 161.08958, 164.…
$ total_num_trips         <dbl> 299, 218, 333, 481, 190, 191, 208, 216, 661, 2…
$ avg_delay_all_departing <dbl> 0.7520067, 1.2635177, 1.1392570, 1.4062153, 1.…
$ avg_delay_all_arriving  <dbl> 0.4198439, 1.1375576, 1.5863956, 4.7885417, 6.…
$ num_late_at_departure   <dbl> 15, 10, 20, 36, 16, 18, 49, 24, 141, 23, 33, 5…
$ num_arriving_late       <dbl> 17, 23, 19, 61, 38, 18, 38, 37, 122, 26, 64, 6…
$ delay_cause             <chr> "delay_cause_external_cause", "delay_cause_ext…
$ delayed_number          <dbl> 0.25000000, 0.25000000, 0.21428571, 0.15517241…



international_trains <- small_trains %>% 
  filter(service == "International") 


international_connections <- international_trains %>% 
  group_by(departure_station, arrival_station) %>% 
  summarise(average_journey_time = weighted.mean(journey_time_avg, total_num_trips)) %>% 
  mutate(outgoing = arrival_station %in% international_stations,
         connection = if_else(outgoing, str_c(departure_station, arrival_station, sep = " - "), str_c(arrival_station, departure_station, sep = " - ")))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'departure_station'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

international_delay <- international_trains %>% 
  group_by(arrival_station, departure_station) %>% 
  summarise(average_arriving_delay = weighted.mean(avg_delay_all_arriving, num_late_at_departure), 
            average_departing_delay = weighted.mean(avg_delay_all_departing, num_late_at_departure)) %>% 
  left_join(international_connections, by = c("departure_station", "arrival_station")) %>% 
  mutate(average_journey_time2 = average_journey_time) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = c("average_arriving_delay", "average_journey_time", "average_departing_delay")) %>% 
  mutate(name = if_else(
    outgoing, 
    str_c("outgoing_", name),
    str_c("incoming_", name)
  )) %>% 
  mutate(name = factor(name, levels= c("outgoing_average_arriving_delay", "outgoing_average_journey_time", "outgoing_average_departing_delay", "incoming_average_departing_delay", "incoming_average_journey_time", "incoming_average_arriving_delay")),
         connection = factor(connection, levels = c("PARIS EST - FRANCFORT", "PARIS EST - STUTTGART", "PARIS LYON - GENEVE", "PARIS LYON - LAUSANNE", "PARIS LYON - ZURICH", "PARIS LYON - ITALIE", "PARIS LYON - BARCELONA", "MARSEILLE ST CHARLES - MADRID"))
         ) 

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'arrival_station'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

international_delay %>% 
  # filter(connection == "PARIS EST - FRANCFORT") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = outgoing, y = value, fill = name)) + 
    geom_col(width = 0.5) + 
    coord_flip() +
    facet_wrap(connection ~ ., ncol = 1, strip.position = "left") + 
    # TODO arrow for direction
  
    labs(x = "", y = "Train delays") + 
  
    theme(
      
      axis.text.y = element_blank(),
      legend.position = "none"
    )

  mutate(time_to_market = decision_date - date_of_opinion) %>% 
  filter(category=="human", !generic, !biosimilar, time_to_market>0) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = time_to_market, y = orphan_medicine)) + 
    geom_violin()

Don't know how to automatically pick scale for object of type <difftime>.
Defaulting to continuous.

objectID: 2023-03-14 - European Drug Development/2023-03-14 - European Drug Development.html#orphan-drugs
href: 2023-03-14 - European Drug Development/2023-03-14 - European Drug Development.html#orphan-drugs
title: European Drug Development
text:
Orphan drugs

jack_bush_palette <- paletteer_d("lisa::JackBush_1")
names(jack_bush_palette) <- c("Drug authorised", "Drug withdrawn", "Orphan drug authorised", "Orphan drug withdrawn")
jack_bush_palette

<colors>
#A1D8B6FF #D2C48EFF #F45F40FF #F9AE8DFF #80B9CEFF 

theme_set(theme_minimal())
theme_update(
  # Legend Styling
  legend.title = element_blank(), 
  legend.position = "none", 
  
  # Title Styling
  plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 16),
  plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
  
  
  #
  panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
  
  # Margins
  plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 20, b = 20, l = 20),
)


orphan_drugs_years <- drugs %>% 
  mutate(year = year(date_of_opinion)) %>%  # date_of_opinion, decision_date, first_published, marketing_authorisation_date, revision_date
  filter(!is.na(year)) %>% 
  group_by(orphan_medicine, authorisation_status) %>% 
  count(year) %>% 
  mutate(authorisation_status = if_else(authorisation_status=="authorised", T, F),
         approved_orphan = case_when(
           orphan_medicine & authorisation_status ~ "Orphan drug authorised",  # TRUE/TRUE
           orphan_medicine & !authorisation_status ~ "Orphan drug withdrawn",  # TRUE/FALSE
           !orphan_medicine & authorisation_status ~ "Drug authorised",   # FALSE/TRUE
           !orphan_medicine & !authorisation_status ~ "Drug withdrawn"   # FALSE/FALSE
         ) %>% factor(levels=c("Drug withdrawn", "Drug authorised", "Orphan drug withdrawn", "Orphan drug authorised")))  

orphan_drugs_years

# A tibble: 82 × 5
# Groups:   orphan_medicine, authorisation_status [4]
   orphan_medicine authorisation_status  year     n approved_orphan
   <lgl>           <lgl>                <dbl> <int> <fct>          
 1 FALSE           TRUE                  1995     4 Drug authorised
 2 FALSE           TRUE                  1996     7 Drug authorised
 3 FALSE           TRUE                  1997     5 Drug authorised
 4 FALSE           TRUE                  1998    15 Drug authorised
 5 FALSE           TRUE                  1999    13 Drug authorised
 6 FALSE           TRUE                  2000    17 Drug authorised
 7 FALSE           TRUE                  2001     7 Drug authorised
 8 FALSE           TRUE                  2002    13 Drug authorised
 9 FALSE           TRUE                  2003     8 Drug authorised
10 FALSE           TRUE                  2004    16 Drug authorised
# ℹ 72 more rows



orphan_years_plot <- orphan_drugs_years %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=year, y=n, fill=approved_orphan)) + 
  geom_col() + 
  
  scale_fill_manual(values=jack_bush_palette, breaks=c("Drug authorised", "Drug withdrawn", "Orphan drug authorised", "Orphan drug withdrawn")) + 
  
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(1995, 2020, 5)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0, 120, 20)) +

  # Number below horizon
  geom_text(data = orphan_drugs_years %>% filter(approved_orphan == "Orphan drug authorised"), aes(label=n), colour="#F45F40FF", y = -2, fontface="bold") +
  
  labs(x = "Year of Opinion",
       y = "Number of Drugs", 
       title = "Number of drugs evaluated by the \n European Medicines Agency each year",
       subtitle = "Submissions for orphan designation lagged after the EU orphan regulation became \neffective in 2000. In 2022, only 20 orphan drugs were submitted for evaluation.",
       # caption = "Data source: European Medicines Agency",
  ) +
  
  theme(
    # Legend Styling
    legend.position = "bottom", 
    legend.box.background = element_rect_round(fill = "white", colour = "black"),
  )

orphan_years_plot









orphan_drugs_summary <- orphan_drugs_years %>% 
  group_by(orphan_medicine, approved_orphan) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(n)) %>% 
  ungroup %>% group_by(orphan_medicine) %>% add_tally(total) %>% ungroup %>% 
  mutate(perc = round(total / n, 2), perc2 = round(n / sum(total), 2))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'orphan_medicine'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

orphan_drugs_summary

# A tibble: 4 × 6
  orphan_medicine approved_orphan        total     n  perc perc2
  <lgl>           <fct>                  <int> <int> <dbl> <dbl>
1 FALSE           Drug withdrawn           105  1063   0.1  0.88
2 FALSE           Drug authorised          958  1063   0.9  0.88
3 TRUE            Orphan drug withdrawn     15   146   0.1  0.12
4 TRUE            Orphan drug authorised   131   146   0.9  0.12

orphan_total_plot <- orphan_drugs_summary %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = orphan_medicine, y = total, fill = approved_orphan)) + 
  geom_col() + 
  
  # Number below the horizon
  geom_text(data = orphan_drugs_summary %>% filter(approved_orphan %in% c("Orphan drug authorised", "Drug authorised")), aes(label=n), y=-20, fontface="bold", colour="black") + 
  
  # Percentage of approval
  geom_text(data = orphan_drugs_summary %>% filter(approved_orphan %in% c("Orphan drug authorised", "Drug authorised")), aes(label=percent(perc)), position = position_stack(vjust = .5), colour="darkgray", fontface="bold") + 
  
  # Percentage of orphan drugs total
  geom_text(data = orphan_drugs_summary %>% filter(approved_orphan %in% c("Orphan drug authorised", "Drug authorised")), aes(label=percent(perc2)), y=1100, fontface="bold", size=6) + 
  
  scale_fill_manual(values=jack_bush_palette, breaks=c("Drug authorised", "Drug withdrawn", "Orphan drug authorised", "Orphan drug withdrawn")) +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c("FALSE" = "Drugs", "TRUE" = "Orphan drugs")) +  # rename orphan drugs T/F
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1200, 200), expand = expansion(mult = c(0.05, 0.15))) +
  
  
  labs(x = "",
       y = "Number of Drugs", 
       title = "Total Number of drugs evaluated by the \n European Medicines Agency (1995-2022)",
       subtitle = "Orphan drugs are 12% of drugs approved while authorisation \n rates are around 90% for orphan drugs and regular drugs.",
       # caption = "Data source: European Medicines Agency"
  ) +
  
  theme(
    axis.title.x = element_blank()
  )

orphan_total_plot









Orphan_drugs_plot <- wrap_plots(orphan_years_plot, orphan_total_plot, ncol = 2, nrow = 1, widths = c(1, 0.33)) + 
  plot_annotation(title = 'Orphan drugs submitted for evaluation by the European Medicines Agency',
                  subtitle = "",
                  caption = "Data source: European Medicines Agency",
                  
                  # tag_levels = 'A', tag_prefix = "Plot ",
                  theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 32)))

Orphan_drugs_plot







ggsave("Orphan drugs plot.png", Orphan_drugs_plot, path="Plots", width = 5400, height = 3000, units = "px", bg="white")
